Yes, friars did face some criticism and opposition from within the Church itself. One of the main criticisms was that they were seen as a threat to the traditional monastic way of life. Monks lived within cloisters and were devoted to a contemplative life of prayer, work, and study. Some people felt that friars were too focused on preaching and ministering to people outside the monastery and were neglecting their own spiritual growth.

Another criticism was that friars were challenging the authority of the bishops, who were responsible for overseeing the clergy within their dioceses. Friars were often independent and could move between different dioceses without seeking permission from the local bishop. This caused tension and conflict between friars and bishops over issues of authority and control.

Moreover, there was also tension between different groups of friars. For example, the Franciscans and the Dominicans had different interpretations of the role of poverty in the life of a Christian. The Dominicans embraced poverty as a means of detachment from worldly goods, while the Franciscans saw poverty as a way of imitating the life of Christ and living in solidarity with the poor. These differences led to debates and disagreements, which sometimes became heated and divisive.

Despite these challenges and criticisms, friars continued to play an important role in the Church and were instrumental in spreading Christianity throughout Europe and beyond.
